briefOverview: Revelation directing church leaders to establish an enduring order and storehouse to care for the poor, emphasizing equality, covenantal stewardship, and promises of celestial blessings.
summary: The Lord instructs Joseph Smith and other leaders to organize an order to regulate a storehouse for the poor in both their current location and the land of Zion, for a permanent system in the church. He stresses equality in temporal things as a preparation for receiving heavenly things and commands them to counsel together, warning that otherwise Satan will blind them. They are to bind themselves by an everlasting covenant, with loss of church standing for those who break it. Through this order the church will, despite tribulations, stand independent and be prepared to inherit crowns and rule. The Lord invokes Michael and Adam-ondi-Ahman, promises guidance to his “little children,” and links thankfulness with multiplied temporal blessings. He identifies himself as the Redeemer and affirms that the church of the Firstborn will be taken up and that faithful, wise stewards will inherit all things.
externalContext: This revelation was given in March 1832 in Kirtland, Ohio, during a period when early Latter-day Saints were establishing two centers of gathering—Kirtland and Zion (Independence, Missouri). Economic and logistical demands led leaders to formalize systems for welfare, publishing, and mercantile activities. The instruction to create a storehouse reflects ongoing implementation of the “law of consecration,” wherein members deeded surplus to the church and received stewardships. Newel K. Whitney, a bishop and businessman in Kirtland, played a key role in church temporal affairs. The covenantal “order” formed here was later referred to as the United Firm, intended to coordinate resources across Kirtland and Missouri for the benefit of the poor and the church’s missions.
externalReferences: The mandate to establish a storehouse and ensure temporal equality echoes earlier teachings on consecration and stewardship (Doctrine and Covenants 42:30–39; 51:3–13). The phrase “church of the Firstborn” parallels Doctrine and Covenants 76:54, and “Michael your prince” reflects language from Daniel 12:1; the promise of receiving “an hundred fold” and the commendation of a “faithful and wise steward” recall Matthew 19:29/Mark 10:29–30 and Luke 12:42. The image of being taken up “in a cloud” resonates with 1 Thessalonians 4:17.
practicalQuestions: How can our community structure welfare and charitable efforts so that the poor are cared for sustainably and fairly?
Where might we need to pursue greater equality in temporal matters to better prepare for spiritual blessings?
What covenants or commitments guide my stewardship, and how can I honor them with integrity?
In what specific ways can I cultivate thankfulness so that I receive both spiritual and temporal blessings as the text promises?
How can leaders and members counsel together effectively to avoid deception and maintain unity in difficult times?
uncertainAreas: The precise scope of the “bond or everlasting covenant” (whether confined to the specific order formed here or extending more broadly) is not fully specified. The references to Adam-ondi-Ahman and being “taken up in a cloud” leave open questions about timing and literal versus symbolic fulfillment. The operational details of the order (e.g., governance, membership, and enforcement beyond loss of office) are not fully delineated in the chapter.
